This panel of Adam delving, and another representing part of the Expulsion of Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden, were brought to Mulbarton in the early 19th century but actually belong to an Old Testament series in the south aisle of Martham church in Norfolk, where a panel of Eve Spinning may still be seen. The style of the fine head of Adam in the Mulbarton panels (with grave, expressive features, painted in a soft sketchy technique) can be recognized in other Norfolk glass, notably in two of the three panels showing scenes from the Passion of Christ in the east window of St Peter Mancroft Norwich. This Passion Master, whose work seems to date from around the 1460s, provides an interesting link between the softer and more naturalistic facial painting of the first half of the century and the more linear and conventionalized Norwich School head-types of the second half, as seen in the much later glass at St Peter Mancroft.
